articles.headline: Fight to Keep Alternative Energy Local Stymies an Industry
articles.snippet: Some officials and residents are promoting less centralized energy-generating systems instead of giant transmission networks, and conflict is growing.
articles.abstract: Some officials and residents are promoting less centralized energy-generating systems instead of giant transmission networks, and conflict is growing.
articles.lead_paragraph: COWGILL, Mo. — Up and down the center of the country, winds rip across plains, ridges and plateaus, a belt of unharnessed energy capable of powering millions of customers, with enormous potential to help meet national goals to stem climate change.

articles.headline: Why You May Want a Smaller iPhone, and Your Questions Answered
articles.snippet: Brian X. Chen of The Times answers readers’ questions about the new iPhone, which combines a four-inch screen with some features from bigger models.
articles.abstract: Brian X. Chen of The Times answers readers’ questions about the new iPhone, which combines a four-inch screen with some features from bigger models.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is hard to turn back after going big. When people moved up to big-screen televisions, nobody wanted to switch back to small TVs. Larger computer monitors have also ruined smaller screens for many people.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Dismisses Rivals for ‘Reckless Actions’ in Foreign Policy
articles.snippet: Speaking in the heart of Silicon Valley, Hillary Clinton called for an “intelligence surge” to defeat the Islamic State and offered a sharp rebuke to the national security credentials of her Republican presidential rivals.
articles.abstract: Speaking in the heart of Silicon Valley, Hillary Clinton called for an “intelligence surge” to defeat the Islamic State and offered a sharp rebuke to the national security credentials of her Republican presidential rivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: In her most vigorous assault yet on her Republican rivals, Hillary Clinton on Wednesday ridiculed the foreign policy prescriptions of Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz, calling them “reckless actions” that would alienate America’s closest allies, demonize Muslims and empower Russia.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: At New York Auto Show, a Parade of New Models
articles.snippet: Vehicle sales are running at a record pace, which means the car industry is willing to invest in new products and technology.
articles.abstract: Vehicle sales are running at a record pace, which means the car industry is willing to invest in new products and technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vehicle sales in the United States are running at a record pace, prompting automakers to consider ways to capitalize on the boom times.

articles.headline: F.B.I. Clash With Apple Loosed a Torrent of Possible Ways to Hack an iPhone
articles.snippet: The prominence of the case has stimulated people worldwide to try to get into the device, and now the government has to check out their ideas.
articles.abstract: The prominence of the case has stimulated people worldwide to try to get into the device, and now the government has to check out their ideas.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For weeks, the United States government has said that the only way to open an iPhone used by a gunman in a mass shooting was to get Apple’s help, a position that set off a clash between the technology giant and law enforcement.

articles.headline: As Siblings Again Unite to Unleash Terror, Experts Ask What Drives Them
articles.snippet: Khalid and Ibrahim el-Bakraoui join a list of brothers involved in nearly every major terror attack on Western soil since three sets of Saudi siblings helped carry out the 9/11 attacks.
articles.abstract: Khalid and Ibrahim el-Bakraoui join a list of brothers involved in nearly every major terror attack on Western soil since three sets of Saudi siblings helped carry out the 9/11 attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: The identification of Khalid and Ibrahim el-Bakraoui as suicide bombers in the deadly Brussels attacks is confronting investigators and counterterrorism experts with a disturbingly recurrent question: Why do so many terrorists turn out to be brothers?
articles.byline: By Jim Yardley, Rukmini Callimachi and Scott Shane

articles.headline: Art Basel Hong Kong Opens to Less Frenzy
articles.snippet: Some dealers noted that the atmosphere seemed more muted than last year, with fewer collectors in attendance and less frenetic first-day buying.
articles.abstract: Some dealers noted that the atmosphere seemed more muted than last year, with fewer collectors in attendance and less frenetic first-day buying.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The first floor of the Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Center was already bustling when Lin Han arrived at the opening of Art Basel Hong Kong, Asia’s most important art fair.

articles.headline: Entire Yahoo Board Would Be Ousted if Starboard Value Gets Its Way
articles.snippet: The increasingly exasperated activist hedge fund, which memorably tormented Darden Restaurants, the Olive Garden owner, is seeking to claim its biggest corporate scalp yet.
articles.abstract: The increasingly exasperated activist hedge fund, which memorably tormented Darden Restaurants, the Olive Garden owner, is seeking to claim its biggest corporate scalp yet.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Tensions between Yahoo and its most outspoken shareholder, the activist hedge fund Starboard Value, were already running high when the two sides agreed early this year on a face-to-face meeting in Manhattan.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Vindu Goel

articles.headline: Despite Efforts, Ted Cruz Was Unable to Steer Half Sister Back on Track
articles.snippet: As Mr. Cruz’s life was taking off, his half sister’s was going in the opposite direction, through bad choices, bad luck and a losing battle with drugs.
articles.abstract: As Mr. Cruz’s life was taking off, his half sister’s was going in the opposite direction, through bad choices, bad luck and a losing battle with drugs.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEDIA, Pa. — In 1997, Ted Cruz was a young lawyer on the climb when a pressing family matter pulled him to a seedy motel outside Philadelphia.

articles.headline: Abortion Rights Advocates Cry Foul at New Step in Fetal Tissue Inquiry
articles.snippet: A House committee investigating how the material is obtained plans to issue 17 subpoenas, a move some call a threat to research and researchers’ lives.
articles.abstract: A House committee investigating how the material is obtained plans to issue 17 subpoenas, a move some call a threat to research and researchers’ lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A special House committee empaneled to investigate fetal tissue research is preparing to issue 17 subpoenas to medical supply companies and laboratories, seeking the names of researchers, graduate students, laboratory technicians and administrative personnel — and prompting charges of intimidation.

articles.headline: Brussels Attack Lapses Acknowledged by Belgian Officials
articles.snippet: The justice and interior ministers said officials might have been lax in passing along information about a terrorism suspect and offered to resign.
articles.abstract: The justice and interior ministers said officials might have been lax in passing along information about a terrorism suspect and offered to resign.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Top Belgian  officials on Thursday acknowledged miscommunications and other errors in the prelude to the Brussels suicide bombings, as growing evidence of links to the Paris assaults by the Islamic State suggested that a wide network of trained attackers leading back to Syria is now rooted in Europe.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin and Rick Gladstone
